results.title: Frontiers of dreams and fears
results.creator_credit: Mai Masri Productions and Mai Masri
results.brief_description: Powerful, passionate and often disturbing “Frontiers of dreams and fears” tells the heart-breaking story of two young Palestinian girls growing up in refugee camps in Beirut and Bethlehem. Firstly we meet 13 year-old Mona who lives in the Shatila refugee camp, Beirut, Lebanon - scene of the of 1982 massacre by the invading Israeli soldiers, with bombed out buildings, high unemployment and low morale. On the other side of the border lives 14 year-old Manar in the Dheisha refugee camp, Bethlehem, Palestine which is controlled by the Israelis. The film focuses on these two young girls, their daily life, their dreams, hopes and aspirations and their friendship which was born through the internet and letter-writing - activities which are made available for the children within the refugee camps. One of the most poignant moments in the film occurs when groups of children, including Mona and Manar, from both camps are able to meet at the Lebanese/Israeli border separated by fences of razor wire. The emotion, both of joy and of sadness, runs high. It is an extremely moving moment. Many of the children from both refugee camps share their hopes and fears to the camera but one always gets the feeling of the underlying tensions that exist even when at times they appear to be giggling and acting light-hearted as teenagers do the world over. However, the desire to return to their homes and their homeland is strong as witnessed by their music, poetry and writings, the longing of the Shatila children to touch the dirt of Palestine and to treasure gifts of Palestinian soil sent from the children of Dheisha. Award-winning Palestinian filmmaker Mai Masri (Children of fire, Children of Shatila, War generation: Beirut) once again has produced a film with sensitivity and a certain freedom of spirit by allowing the children to tell their stories in their own way. Narrated by Nour Chamoun. For more information see www.itvs.org/frontiers

results.title: Frontiers in space
results.creator_credit: David Bennett and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Exploring the universe with telescopes. Explains how astronomers use optical and radio telescopes to gather information about the universe. Shows the world’s largest reflecting telescope at Palomar Observatory in operation.

results.title: Frontiers downunder
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Frontiers downunder”.
The first in a series of six films depicting life in Australia in the late 1970’s. It is a compilation of some of the footage and subject matter of the other five films, and is a very brief look at the complexities that go to make up this huge southland - the largest island in the world. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Frontier college
results.creator_credit: Guy Glover, ONF | NFB and Julian Biggs
results.brief_description: How adult education is brought to the railway and logging camps of Canada’s hinterland. The film tells how university students every summer become “one of the gang” in order to help new immigrants and “old” Canadians acquire some of the knowledge which will enrich their future lives. We are introduced to the founder of Frontier College, Dr. E.W. Bradwin, and witness the experiences of one volunteer who spends his holidays doing double duty as railway section hand by day and teacher by night.

results.title: From Wildman to the Coast
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Bush tucker man series”.
Les Hiddins’ remarkable bushcraft skills have been gained in more than a decade of travel and research in the Top End. They provide the means not only of survival, but also for making life in the bush a little easier: a soap tree used to clean the pots and pans, buffalo dung to repel mosquitoes. Once again, Les demonstrates his ability to eat well in very different environments. He explains how to find water in arid terrain, and advises us not to trust a seemingly innocent-looking fruit. We also discover that the Simpson Desert is no barrier to a man determined to attend a cricket match.

results.title: From war to revolution
results.creator_credit: John Radcliffe and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History 1917-1967”.
Describes the development of the main opposing forces in China in the period of the civil war and disorder following the 1911 revolution, the war with Japan and the eventual establishment of the Communist regime in 1949.

results.title: From the Wet to the Top End
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Bush tucker man series”.
Wild and spectacular countryside forms the backdrop for Les Hiddins’ adventures, including the rock pinnacles of a ‘Lost City’, enormous underground lava tubes and the rugged beauty of the Kimberleys. Les retells the often tragic social history of many of these remote places, such as the failed British garrison at Port Eisington. Along the way, his varied diet includes anything from Barramundi to the Tennis Ball fruit. We see how even Les gets bogged down in the wet lands of Cape York, and follow his explorations of an inland lake in an ingenious canoe made from tree bark.

results.title: From the rainforests to Cape York (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Ashley Smith, David Tunnell, David Leonard, Tim Clark and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Bush tucker man series”.
This video, containing the last four episodes of the series, follows Major Hiddins through the most northern rainforest in Australia at Iron Range, the northern Queensland coastline and the Gulf country, through to the west coast of Cape York where the first known sighting of Australia took place by Europeans.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ashley Smith, David Tunnell, David Leonard, Tim Clark and ABC-TV (Australia)
